awd_titl_txt: CAS: Catalytic Synthesis via Small Molecule Evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemical Synthesis Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Jon Tunge of the University of Kansas is studying the development of strategies that harness the inherent energy in molecules to enable efficient and environmentally sustainable processes for chemical manufacturing. Specifically, the release of small stable molecules (carbon dioxide and/or hydrogen) from simple feedstocks, sometimes in combination with harvesting light energy, will provide the energy to drive chemical reactions without the need for traditional, more wasteful, methods of energy input. To further lessen the environmental impact of the chemistry while also allowing for the exploitation of new types of reaction pathways, catalysts based on cobalt, an earth abundant metal, rather than traditional more expensive and rare precious metals, will be employed as critical promoters. It is anticipated that the methods developed will be applicable to the synthesis of a wide variety of materials with potential applications as pharmaceutical agents, agrochemicals, and other substances of value to science, engineering, and commerce. The broader impacts of the funded project extend to the benefits accrued to society as Professor Tunge and his coworkers engage in outreach and educational activities designed to integrate the goals of this research with training and recruitment programs that incorporate the promotion of 'green chemistry' principles. A significant goal of these activities will be to attract students from diverse backgrounds, including individuals belonging to groups underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields, to address contemporary challenges in sustainable chemistry.

The funded project is focused on the development of chemical transformations based on the catalytic generation of reactive intermediates via the cleavage of C–C and C–H bonds. The catalytic pathways being developed utilize decarboxylation to provide an efficient strategy for the in situ formation of synthetically useful reactive intermediates directly from inexpensive carboxylic acids. Other processes under investigation utilize the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) for atom-economical functionalization. Cobalt catalysts replace traditional, expensive, palladium catalysts in decarboxylative coupling reactions and are anticipated to allow for new transformation types that are inaccessible using current technologies. Additionally, photoredox-catalyzed hydrogen evolution will allow for the site-specific functionalization of amino acids and peptides, while also enabling regiocontrolled decarboxylative Heck-like acylations. These studies will advance a general paradigm for synthetic chemists to use for accessing reactive species under mild conditions, while generating minimal waste using: (1) visible light photoredox catalysts for redox shuffling of transition metal catalysts, and (2) hydrogen evolution to allow oxidative couplings through liberation of the smallest molecule, hydrogen.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
New synthetic strategies and chemical reactions have been developed that rely on the synergistic interaction of two catalysts. One catalyst, a dye, is used to harvest freely available visible light energy and transmit that energy to a second catalyst in the form of electrons. This second, activated catalyst effects the remodeling of common natural chemicals like peptides and amino acids through the evolution of small molecules like carbon dioxide and hydrogen. The reactions and strategies developed as a result of this funding provide chemists with more efficient and less wasteful methods to make chemicals of interest as materials or pharmaceuticals.  Capturing the energy resulting from loss of carbon dioxide allows the generation of reactive chemical species from stable, non-toxic precursors. This obviates the use of toxic, high-energy chemicals that are typically necessary to accomplish similar transformations. In addition, remodeling of chemicals by loss of small, low molecular weight molecules avoids the creation of large quantities of metal-containing toxic pollutants.

Examples of reactions developed include decarboxylative coupling reactions, where the loss of carbon dioxide facilitates forging new chemical bonds for synthesis. Here, base-metal cobalt catalysts were utilized for decarboxylative allylation reactions and decarboxylative difluoroalkylation reactions for the first time. It was further discovered that photoredox catalysts enable decarboxylative addition to simple maleic anhydrides in Giese-type reactions. In contrast to standard Giese additions, these reactions proceed through addition-decarboxylation reactions, giving rise to carboxylic acid products that are normally unstable to such reaction conditions. Importantly, this sets the stage for iterative decarboxylative couplings, where one carboxylic acid is converted into another. In totality, methods developed through this funding have provided greener, environmentally benign reactions to construct product molecules that have high utility. Beyond the synthetic utility of such reactions, important basic scientific knowledge was created which instructs the chemistry community how these reactions proceed and further inspires next-generation innovation. 

Beyond the creation of fundamental knowledge and practical procedures for the synthesis of useful chemicals, funding has supported student training. Here, graduate and undergraduate students have been trained in the green chemistry principles. Thus, industries that they join in the future will be poised to minimize their environmental impact. Outreach efforts have also communicated green chemistry principles to the next generation of scientists and have provided mentorship to students from underrepresented backgrounds with the goal of facilitating their inclusion in chemistry graduate education programs across the country.  

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2023
Modified by: Jon A Tunge
